element_texts.text: Completed

[3 in top left corner]
The Brush & Pencil are To reproduce The Indians in larger size and I am to get a commission The Santa Fe R.R. are thinking seriously of getting up a calender of my Indian portraits which I will get a good sum for. I wrote quite a long article about Indians (The Indians side of his story) and The Carters Magazine is to publish it in June it will be illustrated the article is principally about Chief Victoria* & the Apache Kid both Apaches, stories that were told me by men who were in the spot! a good deal has been written about them but it was the white mans side and not the truth,
Suppose you have seen McNeil what in the world does he unclear

Victorio
Completed

Indians unknown want to do at least 5000 miles away from his models he ought too be here this very minute with the Indians. I have no patience with American Artists who go to Europe for natives to paint when in our own country we have natives that can not be equalled in color or composition any other place in the World and if our American Indians were in Europe, the European government wouldn't have to issue them any rations clothes etc there would be so many Artists painting them that the Indians would be self supporting and I dare say the majority of Artists would be our American Artists but then I am glad it is just  as it is as I have this whole splendid field to my self and inside of ten years it wont be worth while to
Completed

paint the Indians as he will be the same as a white man all his Indian clothes will be gone It is that way now with the majority of Indians I was surprised when I went to ?  Sill this time to see the change in the Indians, they are even giving up their Tepees and using Army tents instead there are now 500 Siouxs camped here and out of 100 Tepees at least 75 are Army tents.
I expect you both are having a fine time.
With love to you both
Am Your affect nephew
Elbridge
Completed

6/4/99
Pine Ridge S. Dak.

June 4, 99
My dear Uncle
Yours of June 2nd recd "Have you recd" The buck skin drawing by Naiche yet?
A Sioux here has made me a fine drawing on painting on buck skin
The Doctor hut has got the finest Buffalo robe I ever saw it is one of the silk robes and on the Tan side it is covered with a beautiful design in unknown work which are very rare and the only one I ever saw I think it can be bought for $100.00 but not less as some time ago he was offered that for it.
I am thinking seriously of
Completed

exhibiting at The Art Institute am disgusted with Thurber and the more I know him the less like him I am getting the best subjects here of any place have been to. such magnificent costumes and fine Types and I will remain here until Fall if my health will let me. I haven't been very well but am taking good care of my self and guess I can manage to remain here I need a good long rest more than any thing else.
I think Red Cloud will sit for me all right but he is the hardest Indian to manage I have had. He has a fine Indian costume. All the important Chiefs have promised to sit including American Horse The Indian who sat for Rosa Bonheur in Paris is to
Completed

sit for me his name is Black Heart I have painted Chief Stinking Bear & Chief Blue Horse- two noted Indians I don't loose any time here at all as I have Indians waiting for their turn to sit  The squaws dress up in the best Indian style of any Indians have been to have painted one squaw so far, just finished one where it took me 5 days to paint I would like to have my exhibition at the Art Institute in connection with their exhibition which comes off in Nov and I would like a small room to my self. Since have commenced to paint Indians have painted in all 182 
[bottom right notation 6-4-99}
Completed

Have you had a talk with Mr Kimball of Brush & Pencil Wish you would some time and get his unknown- maybe rims? on the Indians color plates, he is a bright square honest man and will do something with the color plates.
I would like to be at Seneca Lake for a while but I prefer it here in he prairie for some time yet. The next exhibition I have will be more interesting to the general public as the Indians have painted this time are those who use feathers beads etc more extensively
Your affectionately nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Pine Ridge
June 7/ 99 S. Dak.
My Dear Uncle
I received word from Thurber today that the buckskins I had ordered painted for you by Naiche had been sent to them with bill. I left explicit directions before leaving Ft. SIll for the buckskins to be sent to you but I think the proprietor of the Indian trading store was absent and the clerk sent the buckskin to Thurbers
Completed

I have written Thurber to send the buckskin to you at Old Colony Bldg.  I am painting Chief Spotted Elk now and Chief Red Cloud sent word to me today by an Indian[s] that he would sit for me when I was through with Spotted Elk.
You would of laughed to of seen a Doctor who has been here a few days sight seeing.  Some of the Siouxs are the worst beggars I ever saw so I told them the Doctor had lots of money and some old clothes but that
Completed

he was a little stingy and that by a good deal of teasing and talking they could get a good deal out of him so they went for him.  They gave him no rest.  His room was next to mine and he couldn't go to his room to take a nap or lie down but what the Indians were after him. The Doctor didn't understand a bit of Sioux and the Indians very little English and it was fun and laughable to hear them, some times the Doctor would ask me
Completed

to explain which I did in an exagerated way, just before the Doctor left Chief Spotted Elk shook hands with him and then told the Doctor with a mixture of Sioux & English that all the coat he had was what he had on and asked him if he wouldn't give him his coat. The Doctor explained that the coat he had on was the only one he had with him. The Indian answered him in Sioux which the Doctor ? I did not understand but the Doctor said to me what did he say then. I replied that he
Completed

said he didn't want to take the only coat you had with you but that there was lots of good coats at the Indian traders store that would fit him. The Doctor appeared glad to hear that the stage was ready to go, and all the talking the Indians did with him one Indian got 10 cents.  Chief American Horse was in to see me today he wants more unclear than I am giving the others which I will not give him as he is
Completed

just the kind of a man to brag about it to the other Indians but I will get him all right.  One thing I like about the Apaches they are honorable & so trust worthy and especially Geronimo. I paid him twice what I did the others a day and I did not ask him not to tell the other Apaches but he took it for granted that I wouldn't like it and he did not tell them and if any of the Apaches were present when I went to pay Geronimo he
Completed

would go out side for me to pay him there.  If he and lots of the other Apaches had a chance when young he would of made a smart man and a good man he is as kind as he can be to his own people and the devotion that he shows his poor sick wife & child is to his credit.  I recd. a letter from Thos V. Kearn. he expects to go to England this year I guess for good. 
Your affect. nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

6/17/99
Pine Ridge  S. Dak
June 17/99
My dear Uncle
I hardly think now I will be able to get a portrait of Red Cloud, he has been made so much of by Eastern people that he is spoiled  the people but who know him  don’t think much of him as he is unreliable and not the Chief that Little Wound is and not the man he is, or Blue Horse
Completed

who is one of the best Indians I know perfectly reliable and trust worthy and have done more to induce the Sioux Indians to be friendly with the whites than any other Sioux he has saved the lives of a great many whites. I met a man here the other day who has lived here more than 21 years told me where Blue Horse saved his life & 15 other white people from the Siouxs he said he never saw a man work harder than Chief Blue Horse did to prevent the 


                                4218
Completed

Indians from killing the whites and the Government never has done any thing for him while they have built a good two story house for Red Cloud and done lots of favors for him Red Cloud promised to sit for me faithfully and now he has backed out
This eve I  went over to his house. to see about renting an Indian buckskin shirt of his It is a fine one Red Cloud and a lot of Indians were in the house  he got the shirt.
Completed

out and I offered  him a dollar to let me take it, he wanted $2.00 which I would not give finally one of the Indians said Red Cloud says if you dont want to pay $2.00 you can take it and when he says a thing he means it, I says you tell Red Cloud he is a dam liar he told me he would sit for me and now he will not and I turned and left,  I am getting some fine subjects here all I an attend to 
The Indians are to have big times here on the  4th of July
Completed

Some relative of mine by marriage a woman has been circulating some false statements about me saying that I am immoral and chase after women etc which doesn't make me feel very good  
If there is a man on this Earth that is true to his wife and tries to do what is right & honorable I am that man and I will defy any one to say different
She is not satisfied to talk about me
6-17-99
Completed

but has to circulate false statements about my wife
The reason I write this to you is because thought you might of heard the report which makes me very unhappy 
I wish all liars and deceitful people could be placed on some island by them selves.
There is an Indian here named Sword who years ago was one of the most brutal Indians he used to commit the most horrible deeds but now he is reformed and a Minister and
Completed

a very smart man and one of the best Indian artists I have seen, he is painting on buck skins for me
The ghost dance & the sun dance 
now  I dont like to order any for you because I dont know how you like the buck skins
Naiche painted for you I dont know whether  you have received it I have asked you but you do not answer
If the one Naiche did for  you is like mine it is fine, The green design on it
Completed

are medicine designs and worn by the Apaches years ago
the Mahohly? also has painted on it flowers that grow in Arizona and also Butterflies that are in Arizona.
It is getting pretty hot here for the prairie, if it gets too hot to work so the Indians wont sit
I may go where Chief Joseph? is where it is nice & cool in the  mountains he has promised to sit for two portraits

and there are other Indians there I could paint also but I think I wont have any trouble here & can remain until Fall

With love to you from your affectionate nephew  Elbridge
Completed

July 9/99. Pine Ridge. S. Dak.
My dear Uncle
I have at last got Red Cloud to sit for me and have got one of the best portraits ever painted of him he had on a fine buck skin coat he has had for years and a chiefs feathers on his head. He sat fine wouldn't take a rest but sat all day without resting 

I had a time to get him had a regular
Completed

fuss with him  I painted him in his own home he offered all kinds of excuses not to sit
I asked him what he would take for his buck skin jacket he said may be he would make me a present of it.  I have it now in my room.
I may possibly get him to sit for another picture  American Horse is coming to sit for me in a week and am in hopes of getting Little Wound who today is the most influential chief of the Siouxs
I have painted one
[4218]
Completed

hostile Indian named[ Kicking Bear  a Chief he was on of the finest types I have had and fixed it fine for me.
I may leave here in two or three weeks for the North where Joseph is,  It is getting pretty hot here now to work the heat is very distressing

and one feels like sleeping and I have a hard time to keep the Indians awake  am painting but 

Red Cloud didnt sleep a wink which surprised me
Buffalo Bill has been trying to get
Completed

to go with his show and has offered him $150.00 a month and all expenses but he wont go and at Omaha they have had two different men here to get Red Cloud to the Omaha show with out success he is hard to manage and I am very glad I got him
I let on that I didn't care to paint him and for 6 weeks didnt speak to him at all.  The place I have to eat here is the very worst place I ever was in is
Completed

my life  they have so much of the cheapest canned things to eat will be glad when get where I can get a cup of coffee and some vegetables & butter to eat & some meat.  If it wasn't for Oranges I can buy here I would fare pretty bad.
I know where I can get a genuine red skin Tipi all painted up.
The best Indians Sioux ?trint here was painted for me the Sioux
7-9-99
Completed

sun dances on buck skins which I dont think I will let you see as you probably would want it.  He is going to paint for me the ghost ? dance on a hide.  Red Cloud has got a lot of human scalps 
I may possibly go away if in the extreme N. W. of Washington state for some green? Indians who live there before returning and after my exhibition is over in Chicago am going below City of Mexico for those Indians down there
Completed

I see some man has been down there taking casts of their hands & I have got a good cast of both of Geronimos hands also his finger tip marks
I just got them out of curiosity for some palmist.
I have painted in this trip 55 Indians and 4 darling children including Arapahoe  S. Cheyenne Osage Kiowa  Comanche & Sioux  The Sioux will take the best of all as they are more Indian [[ fied ?] and fixed it fine.  The frames I am getting made
Completed

I will save some $200.00 on wood  they are much more artistic when you see them you will want yours framed since many unclear are thoroughly Indian and many subdued - low in tone and inexpensive.
With love to you both
Am Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Pine Ridge
S. Dak.
July 16/99
My Dear Uncle
Yours of July 13. received & glad to hear from you.
Chief Little Wound is sitting for me
now he is the most
influentive  Indian living now among Indians he always
had and has now more followers than Red Cloud and is 
more of a man than Red Cloud they tell me here that Little
Completed

Wound doesn’t know what a dishonorable thing is and is the 
best liked Indian of all the Sioux’s he 
is a great big tall fellow with a fine commanding voice
has a fine War bonnett & Indian clothes.
Chief American Horse came to day to sit
for me he is a good type speaks fairly good English but I am picking up a good deal
of Sioux it is an easy langogue to learn
Red Cloud killed Little Wounds Father and for a long time
Completed

they were bitter enemies but are friendly now  Red Clouds son came to see his Fathers picture
Today and looked at it a long while he was well pleased with it. Red Cloud is going to sit for another picture so I will have a front view and profile of him with his Indian clothes on. I know how to manage him now I had a hard time to get Little Wound his squaw stays with him all the time. They both eat dinner with me Red Cloud also ate dinner with me. I
Completed

had to help him some as he can scarcely see. The Sioux I am painting will be the best exhibition I have had and take the best as they look like the ideal Indians.
The only draw back here is the fearful Hotel I have to eat in lots of times  I am hungry but when the food is set before me my appetite goes  Once in a while some of the white people write me to dine with them and I could clean the table my self alone.
Completed

It is painted by a Sioux who years ago was one of the worst Indians the Government had to deal with  he would cut women open before they were dead  Today that same man is a Preacher  preaches every Sunday to the Indians goes to the white peoples prayer meeting he dresses like a preacher and is a perfect gentleman and well liked by all  He said he is sorry for the people he has killed but at that time he thought he was doing right  He is painting
Completed

now for me on a skin the Indians made of fighting   he is The 
Silent among the Sioux.  He also is going to paint Red Clouds history for me on a skin and also Sitting Bulls  said he can get Sitting Bulls history from some of the other Indians
I have been wanting to leave here and get where Joseph is but am afraid will stay right here until Fall
When I get American Horse's picture I will have all the important Chief's at Pine Ridge
Completed

Some other time I will go to Rose bud another Agency for the Sioux. as some noted Indians are there like "He Dog" and "Two Sticks" etc
Spotted Tail was there but was murdered by another Indian several years ago.  I will let you see the pictures before the exhibition
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Pine Ridge. 
July 20 1899 S. Dak. 
My dear Uncle
I leave here Today where Joseph is some 1600 miles North of here. I want to get there before those Indians leave for Hop? [hic?]] King
The Indians here are busy  some of them cutting hay and good many of them are going to the Omaha Show and then A is so useful unclear here now
Red Cloud told me he would sit
Completed

for a front view picture when I returned
On my way home I am coming here to finish it with some more Chiefs I want
My address will be  Barry Washington (Nes Pilem)
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Barry Washington
(Nes Pilem)
July 26 1899
My dear Uncle 
I just arrived here last night and it seems as though was in another country. The Columbia River is very high but the Indians got me across all right. This is the first place I have been in such beautiful country 
The little Nes Pilem Agency is all hemmed in by big mountains some of them covered with snow and
Completed

a mountain stream runs with in 100 feed of where I sleep  The purest water to drink and cold as ice and full of trout.  I have gained 4 lbs since left Pine Ridge.  The Agent and Doctor here run a mess of their own have good cook and have a fine garden raise all kinds of vegetables which is irrigated by this mountain stream and I have such fine things to eat no cheap canned vegetables and lots of game to eat  Prairie chicken grouse Ducks Deer etc. I killed a prairie chicken from the wagon
Completed

yesterday, so I am living like a King and eating like a pig.
Joseph is not here but will be in 3 or 4 days he went to Lapway in Idaho some 300 miles on horseback for the 4th of July. There are 5 or 6 different tribes of Indians here viz. Nez Perce Nes Pilem Columbia Snake Umatilla and another tribe in Nes Pilem sits for me tomorrow   Then 40 of them left   Chief Moses is dead so is Chief Rubens
Completed

he and Joseph were the two living
Nez Perce Chiefs will get 2 portraits of Joseph and more if he will sit.  While here will get 2 or 3 of each of the tribes I dread going back to Pine Ridge on account of the fearful place to eat but I will go there on my return home as Red Cloud is to sit again and some 5 or 6 noted Chiefs also. Two block from my room in a big pond and evng unclear lots of ducks in it. There are only 4 white men here and they
Completed

are glad to have me here as they got tired of looking at each other   They looked at me and acted as though I dropped here from the moon.  Very few people come here during a year as it so difficult to get here.  There is scenery in these mountains here that can not be had any place in the World
The Great Northern Rail Road has made it easy of access to Lake Chelan which is a lake 70 miles long and more than 1000 feet above the
Completed

Columbia River and completely surrounded by mountains  There is one place there where a River empties into the crossed out word lake which is 1000 feet above the lake and falls into the lake and they say any fine fishing there.  One can get there on the Great Northern Rail Road which connects with a boat on the Columbia River and then a free bus runs to the Lake a few miles, it is only in the last 15 years that any white people have seen the lake at that time not a single boat was on the lake now
Completed

there are several fine residences there and several boats. In 1886 a party of five of us took images at Spokane and drove 300 miles across the Big Bend country at that time  we wouldn"t see a  human being only one in 40 or 50 miles  The country was wild, now, it is all taken of fine farms and good size towns Spokane was 3000 in population now it is 50000 a regular little Chicago, at that time we intended to visit Lake Chelan
Completed

but lost our way and couldn't find it 
The Lake is 95 miles from here. I wish you and Aunt Emma would visit the Lake some time
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Barry Washington 
Nes Pilem Agency
August 16 1899
My dear Uncle
Chief Joseph came here this week and came to see me when I was working the first thing and was glad to see me but he acts funny  about it, he is hanging off for better pay I think so I am hanging off and painting other Indians in the mean time and Joseph will come around all right.  I have painted one Columbia Indian
Completed

and one Columbia squaw in fine costume they belong to the Moses tribe have also painted one Yackima Indian in fine costume and one Umatilla Indian in fine type and tomorrow a Nes Pilem Indian is to sit for me. There are 8 different tribes of Indians here and 10 different languages spoken at this little Agency   The prevailing language spoken here is Chinook all the Indians in this part of country understand it, it is easy to learn.
For several weeks I have been bothered with my eyes but thought I could put it off until returned
Completed

to Chicago but I was troubled so much the Doctor here advised me to go to an Oculist in Spokane so last week I went there had to ride 100 miles in an old wagon through dust 8 and 12 inches thick  The Oculist told me nothing was the matter but that I had been using them a little severe? and I'm rest there a little so I am taking it easier here working every day
Yesterday afternoon I went hunting and got some Ducks - Pheasants which men find eating  There is fine trout fishing
Completed

here also lots of Deer. There has been some deaths among the Indians here lately and they are busy having great feasts and very solemn ceremonies which are held in great big Tipis  I went to one this afternoon  Joseph was present and gave a very solemn speech.
Joseph is proud of his picture from the Brush and Pencil Magazine he has it hung up in his house
I want the Brush and Pencil on Mr Kimbark to get a color plate of Chief Pretty Eagle  Chief Karag Bonetah and Chief Santos you have. I dont know how long will be here will stay until get one
Completed

or two pictures of Joseph
I had to laugh at him when he seen me he commences to tell me what a pain it gave him in the back to sit and that it made him a little sick.
This is a fine place. The evenings are so cold one has to have 3 and 4 blankets to keep warm.
I have been sleeping in a big barn in the hay but one of the men here has gone on a vacation so I have his bed.
there are only 5 white men here all the time and at first it is hard to understand them as
Completed

they use so many Chinook words in speaking.
With love to you both
Am your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Barry Washington
Nes Pilem Agency
August 30 1899
My dear Uncle
I haven't been able to get Joseph to sit for me yet he has promised to sit but things keep coming up to detain him. He was to sit for me three weeks ago but the Nez Perces gave a bit Potlatch (feast) which lasted two days
Joseph had to be present there after
Completed

that he went to Wilbur 50 miles from here and was gone 4 days but I kept right on painting other Indians and had no attention to Joseph, so one day Joseph came to see me about his sitting what I was to pay him etc. and he agreed to come the next day which was 5 days ago
He has a little vegetable garden right at the Agency here and has a shed built in the garden and next day he and his squaw went to the shed to find his Indian clothes.
Completed

he had a lot of fine Indian curios in there packed in ruined trunks. He said he couldn't find all of his things but would get them and come Monday as the next day was Sunday, it is now Wednesday and he hasn't showed up yet but the Indians tell me he has a lot of hay to cut also oats and is trying to get some Indians to cut it but as all the Indians are going some 300 miles to pick hops Joseph has to cut the hay him self and so little while ago I
Completed

saw Joseph on a load of Oates he stopped and told me he had lots of work to do and had to do it him self. said he couldn't find the beaded necklace that he wore that he probably left it at Lapway in Idaho etc but I told him I could borrow a necklace from some other Indian and he said all right fairly soon he would come, so I am still waiting. Last Sunday 3 of us each with a good horse went up in the mountains hunting for pheasants
Completed

and got a lot of them. I have gained 14 pounds since have been here I weigh now 160 lbs more than ever have weighed.
Just as soon as get Joseph's portrait will leave for the Flathead Indians in Montana.
I have been trying to get a Nes Pilem Indian to sit for me but the trouble is none of them have any Indian clothes and all have their hair cut a Snake Indian is to sit for me soon as he gets through haying
Completed

If you see Mr French of the Art Institute wish you would speak to him about my having an exhibition there this Fall of my Indians.
With love to you and Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew  Elbridge
Completed

Barry Washington
Nes Pilem Agency
September 7 1899
My dear Uncle
I finished yesterday a fine portrait of Joseph had quite a time to get him I painted a three quarter view of him with is Indian clothes on, this picture is an order that I had from two years.
Joseph is to sit for another portrait
Completed

commencing tomorrow am going to paint a profile view of him then I will have painted 3 different views of him. He eats Dinner with me every day, he told me of a lot of Prairie chickens around his place and I went there after work and shot some  am going again. 
Today Am afraid I will have to give up going to The Flathead Indians this time as I must return to the Siouxs at Pine Ridge and I ought to be
Completed

in Chicago October 1st
All the Indians except Joseph and a few have left here for Hop picking and I will leave here in about 6 days for Pine Ridge.
I have had to pay my railroad fare ever since left Oklahoma . T.
Joseph was telling me about an Army Officers son who was in poor health and the son was sent here for his health he was a boy some 12 years old and lived with
Completed

Joseph two years and learned to speak Nez Perse  Joseph said he was a nice boy and they all liked him and did all they could to entertain him, finally the boys Father sent for him to come home but he wouldn't go so he sent a man after him. Joseph said the boy had a sick tum-tum which means very sorry and cried etc but had to go. Joseph seems to think a great deal of me   I have sent him
Completed

(5)
all pictures of his that have been reproduced also articles I have written Indians about Indians sticking up for them which Joseph had translated to him and he said I had said good things about him and that we were clash tilicums , (good friends) 
He asked for my address he said he expected to go to Washington later on and wanted me to meet him in Chicago. I should like to have you meet him and let him see The Illustrated Indians
Completed

book you have, which he would enjoy all Indians are very fond of pictures and especially of Indians in costume years ago like the books you have.
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Pine Ridge  South Dakota
September 19 1899
My dear Uncle
I arrived here all right and feel well repaid for going North as got two good portraits of Joseph. besides the Yackima and Palouse Indians.
Red Cloud is sitting for another portrait for me full front view will have the picture finished tomorrow
Completed

He tried to put me off said he had a sick stomach, showed me his bare belley where a Pawnee Indians had shot an arrow clear through him, the scarr was there all right. 
I am painting him in his house. His squaw a very old woman got a lot of Red Clouds old things out to show me and among them was his Indian pipe and tobacco bag both of them beautifully decorated. I asked her if she would sell them so she asked him and I got the both for $4.00
Completed

I have recieved a letter from an Indian he wrote me a long letter Old Chief Blue Horse he had some one write the letter for him which is very interesting.
Mr Kimbark has been selling a large number of The Indians color plates  They were sold cheap in Chicago but at a loss to the stores  Mr Kimbark gave one store the sole right to sell them at a good price but some of the other stores got the pictures through other stores in other cities which was no
Completed

fault of Mr Kimbarks and could not be helped  I got 10% commission on the sales and am to no bother or expense, some people argue that selling pictures as Mr Kimbark has been doing hurts me. I dont think so because the reproductions we first clear and then besides every one knows that those color plates are inexpensive and can be sold cheap a good article sold cheap hurts no one but a poor article sold dear does hurt any one.
Thurber would of liked
Completed

to have had control of these color plates and charged $1.00 each for and made 800% profit and sit in his chair and do nothing to help sell them and probably sell one when Kimbark sells 5000. Thurber and I haven't settled up yet on the photos he has sold which now amounts to several hundred dollars, they sent me a statement several months ago and nearly $500.00 worth had been sold. When I get back I am going to make some arrangements with Kimbark when here after I am paid
Completed

for every Indian color plate that appears in Brush and Pencil they have had them free now a year. and then I want to see what commission is right for me to receive on the Indian color plate sales  10% may be right for all I know.
I hope you will allow them to reproduce Pretty Eagles pictures as he is so well known that thousands of them would be sold.
When I was in Spokane I went in a bank to get a check cashed and the cashier said
Completed

he had Josephs picture nicely framed in his house which he got from Brush and Pencil.
My father has been writing me in regards to going in together and selling Indians color plates. I wouldnt' like it for several reasons. in the first place it would take a lot of money that is to make a success of it and I think after deducting all expenses and the worry and bother there wouldnt' be more than 10% profit left as the pictures would have to be sold cheap
Completed

25 cents is about all the dealer could get for them and sell lots of them and he wants to make 50% profit for handling them.
As it is now I have no bother as more for about them I can put all my mind in my work. I don't think my Father is any better or as good a business man as I am myself and I am a poor one. if he had been he wouldn't of been a common Railroad Agent for some 35 years.
Mr Kimbark has lots of money to put in
Completed

the business
I will be in Chicago October 2nd and want to have a talk with you. If convenient with you would speak to some of the Art Institute people about my having an exhibition there this Fall, possibly it may be too late now. I hope not.
With love to you both
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Mescalero New Mexico
December 14 1899
My dear Uncle
I arrived here yesterday after 5 long days travel nd am very much disappointed in these Indians they are the most civilized of any Indians have been to, every Indian man has got his hair cut short and they all are self sufficient, they receive no rations at all. The squaws are uninteresting and are awful dirty looking
Completed

set. I will leave soon for Laguna and Acoma New Mexico where I will get some good subjects.
The country is fine here healthy, fine spring water to drink and lots of wild game such as Deer and Wild Turkey had a wild Turkey for Dinner today.
I had a hard time to get accommodations here at the Agency a mile from here  There was absolutely no place for me to eat or sleep but after hunting around found a poor Farmer who lives in a mud house who took me in
The El Paso & N. Eastern
Completed

Rail Road runs with in 17 miles of this place. These Indians make a basket that I had never seen every before came here, you haven't one, they are made of a sort of cactus and all the colours in the basket are different colored cactus  They use no dies whatever  I bought a few for my self.
I sent to Ft Sill and ordered another skin of Naich for you as the one I have I don't like to part with. I have tried to get four or five different
Completed

squaws to sit for me but they are so superstitious that they are afraid  I don't care much as their pictures would not be saleable at all.
These Mescadero Apache are no where near as bright and sweet as Geronimos band
They seem to be a lower class of Apache, Therefore are more superstitious.
Wishing you and Aunt Emma a Happy Christmas
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
PS You can address me to Laguna N. M.
Did you receive the Indian book cover?
Completed

Laguna New Mexico
December 17 1899
My Dear Uncle
I arrived here yesterday. My trip to Mescadero was all for nothing and it seems funny as up to a year ago these Indians have been living 110 miles from a railroad, living was up in the mountains 7000 feet in elevation in a very different country
Completed

to get to and as it is now very seldom a stranger goes there, still they are far advanced towards civilization all of the men have their hair cut short, they are self supporting receive no raitions and each family has its little farm, the principal reason why I went there was a photograph I saw in Chicago of a squaw with a
Completed

beautiful basket on her head and below was printed a Mescalero squaw which was not true as the squaws never carry a basket on the head. It has only been lately that it was safe for a white man to go there as two different bands of cut throats invaded that country Billy the Kid used to live there. Old Chief Victoria the Warm Springs Apache lived there years ago  it is a beautiful country lots of wild game every amount of
Completed

Deer and Wild Turkey I saw a dog eating venison there. The people were very noice to me and wanted me to stay but it wasn't worth my time. I am going to remain here for some time as The Pueblo girls with jars on their heads are very picturesque and saleable and I want to paint a lot of them. The Pueblo girl picture you have her name is Si-Me-Ka is mad at me  I called to see her and she just barely shaked hands with me, she doesn't
Completed

like it because I made her picture (she says) look older than she is, she has one of the reproductions.
I have a nice place to room and eat the cows pass within 100 feet of my room
The through passenger on the Santa Fe from Chicago passes through here at 8.15pm then I go to bed.
I expect Maratta here in a few days and when he comes we will go over to Acoma but I will do most of
Completed

my work here.
Three more of your pictures viz Pretty Eagle, Boneta and White Swan are being reproduced in three colors to complete another set of 21.
You ought to get a Mescadero basket they have some at Albuquerque in the Lunch room but nearly all are not genuine most of them are faked baskets as the genuine Mescadero basket not a single dye is used  The
Completed

(7)
colors used are the natural colord woods? as material used the colors are beautiful very somber because they are natures own color and woven in while most of the baskets at Albuquerque are made by the Mescalos but the pattern on the baskets are died and painted in the basket after it is made  The color is not the same. I got me some 6 baskets, good size for $4.50  all of them In case you want
Completed

any send to Agent Mescalero Indians
Mescalero New Mexico
Wishing you and Aunt Emma a Happy Xmas
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Laguna
N. M.
Completed

Laguna New Mexico
December 26 1899
My Dear Uncle
Yours received and glad to hear from you also received Xmas present from Aunt Emma and letter am much obliged it is nice of her to remember me Xmas.
I also was surprised when I saw the Mescalero Indians as after only a year they have lived
Completed

100 miles from a railroad but the last two Agents there has done every thing to civilize them, They are issuing dresses shoes and unclear to the squaws they look like Mexicans.
I wonder if old man Brazer was in that country when you were he has our old grist mill built of adobe it has been there for over 30 years  The old man died a year ago but his son is there now and runs the old mill.
Completed

Do you remember in the valley just as you go up the Sacramento Mountains a lot of white sand it stretches some 25 miles in length and 10 miles wide  I thought it was snow it is so white, the little Mexican town Tulurasa is located near by
I am fixed find here for work and am getting some good models among the Pueblo squaws am painting.
Them with their jars on their heads, they are curious people  I have to handle them like
Completed

one would the most delicate butterfly, The more white people there are among the Indians the harder time I have to get them to sit as the white people jock them about sitting, here the white people made me some trouble and I had quite a time get the Indians to sit, the white people didn't mean any harm but thought it was funny I gave the white people a talking to so now they are more careful
Mr Bibo the Indians
Completed

Trader here is a great jocker I told him if he jocked any more with the Indians I am painting about their sitting I would jocke with them and tell them the goods he sold had witcher? etc. in them and bad medicine so he is more careful.
Sunday I went over to Acoma and it is a wonderful place stopped and had a good look a the Enchanted Mesa.
I went up the narrow steep track leading to the Acoma village and enjoyed my self.
Completed

the old Church happened to be opened, the Indians were fixing up for a ceremony, the altar was very queer a mixture of Catholic and Indian but to my surprise I saw a large painting hung on the wall next to the Altar that is a masterpiece it is beautifully painted fine drawing and color and was painted by a master in Spain it is in fairly good condition  it is a little mildewed and the canvas here and there worm eaten
Completed

I was so taken with it, stared before it for an hour. I told the Indians if they would give me that picture I would paint them a bran new one just like it, they referred me to a Priest in Santa Fe. The picture is worth thousands of dollars.
I don't think it will be necessary for me to stay at Acoma for the Indians there as they are coming here nearly every day to trade and I can get them to stop over.
Sunday night at
Completed

midnight I saw the Laguna Pueblo Xmas ceremony held in their church which was very curious and weird and interesting their Xmas lasts 4 days in which they dance principally.
The Acomas make much finer pottery than the Lagunas.
There are some Eastern people who have had a kiln built here at several hundred dollars expense and an Eastern lady is here in charge  
The object is to teach these Indians how
Completed

to glaze their pottery which I think a very foolish thing as the Indians pottery is much better the way they make it, at its best it is crude and to glaze it would be out of keeping
The Indians took no stock in it at all and wouldn't allow the house to be built on their lands so finally the Santa Fe leased her railroad land and the house is built close to the tracks but the Indians built the house and charged her good wages.
I want to remain
Completed

here some time and paint quite a number of those squaws especially as the pictures are saleable
I expect Maratta here in a few days, he probably will spend most of his time at Acoma.
Am glad you like the Indian book cover. a relative of Red Clouds made it. I think it would be a good idea to have the Indians water colors bound in the cover.
Wishing you and Aunt Emma a Happy New Year  Your affectionate Nephew Elbridge
Completed

12/31/99
Laguna, New Mexico
Dec 31/99
My Dear Uncle 
Enclosed find loan? to be renewed wish you would also send the other losses?. I want to tell you about some pictures I sent to Reinhardt in Milwaukee Wis I met him at Deakins he Reinhardt has a fine Art Gallery There on same floor Deakins is on and he said he wanted me to send some of my Indian pictures to Milwaukee so a few days before leaving Chicago Mr Sunsanlus? a son of the Minister and who is Reinhardts manager in his Chicago gallery told me
Completed

Reinhardt wanted me to send some Indian pictures over to Milwaukee so I picked out 46 of the best ones and before sending them asked if he would insure them and I received no reply. I wrote again told him Milwaukee had a bad reputation for fires and I wanted the pictures insured and no reply, the pictures were all boxed waiting at Thurbers so the day I left I had the 46 pictures sent to Reinhardt and wrote him to ensure them for $5000 and if I was right I would start? the insurance and to let me know if he would insure them. Also wrote him that the pictures had been sent and to let me know if they arrived and I recd " 
4218
Completed

no answer I have written him again and told him that
Klackner of New York wanted these pictures in Jan and they
must be returned to Thurber by Jan 1st and asked him
again if he would let me known something about them
when they were to be exhibited if they arrived in good order
if they were insured etc and do  you know that man refuses
to even write me a postal card I haven't heard one 
word from him and much it worries me, if I was 
in Chicago I would go to Milwaukee and show 
him how they do business out West. Your Uncle
Completed

Ed I don't mean to bother

you about this but I don't know
who to go to, to see about these
pictures, there must be some
reason for that mans silence
The 46 pictures cost me
several hundred dollars to get
and I don't want to quit here
and go to Milwaukee but
I must do it rather than 
to have my unclear unclear
done Reinhardt bears a high
reputation an old established Art dealer.
If you just as soon as you might
telephone over to him his
name is Henry Reinhardt
10 Grand Avenue. Milwaukee W's
I am quite sure the pictures
are not on exhibition yet
as there would be surely
something in the papers about them, and I belong
Completed

(5)
to a clipping bureau and 
have read nothing as yet
of such as exhibition.
I will enclose an order?
for those pictures and if you
think that? get them and
have them delivered back 
to Thurber 210 Wabash Ave.
The New York Herald is to 
have a full page illustrated
of my Indians yesterday I
recd a telegram from Harper
wanting to know if they could
reproduce Chief Spotted 
Elk from the magazine
I have some Indians more
on exhibition in N.Y. Academy
Two of my Indians have

been sold to a relation of 

Carnegie in Florida.
I am getting along fine here
Expect Maratta this week.
The new set of Indian reproductions are
Completed

selling fine so they write me
With love to you and Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
P.S. I will address this letter
to you and Aunt Emma in
case you are out of city.
Completed

Laguna.
Jan 5. 1900. N.M.
My dear Uncle
I finally heard from Reinhardt 3 weeks after sending pictures to him. I never will send any more pictures to him.
I am getting along fine here am getting all the models can paint.
If I go out to Acoma to stay will have to do my own cooking as there is no place to stop there for a white man. unless ate with the Indians and I would'nt care to do that they are so dirty. The woman I stop with here is a Pueblo Indian but she has been to
Completed

Carlyle School and is a fine cook very neat & clean.
I need a letter from Prof Hodge of the Smithsonian wanting the catalogues of my different exhibitions. I hav'nt any only the last one so sent him a list of Indians have painted Mrs Seton Thompson has a story in Jan Painter entitled "A woman tenderfoot in the Rockies" I appear in the story, which is a true one she calls me Barfield.
With love to you both
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Laguna.
N.M.
Jan 11. 1900.
My dear Uncle
Yours at hand with passes enclosed which am much obliged for.
Am glad the pictures that Reinhardt had of mine are back at Thurbers.
I am getting along fine here am working on my 8th Pueblo picture am painting all of them with the Acoma jars on their head, at present am painting the belle of the Laguna Pueblos who is a very pretty girl. I have all the models can paint now have them waiting for their turn, and expect to remain here some time yet
Completed

but the high altitude here bothers me, evry since have been here. have had a ringing noise in my head which is annoying.
Have you made any definite plans about sending to Paris a lot of Indian pictures like you spoke of before I left Chicago?
I think  the team that you and Aunt Emma started for Acoma behind is the very same team & wagon that took me to Acoma which was a big horse and a barrow hitched together and I thought the wagon would fall to pieces before we finished the journey but it held out. I told the man who owns the team that I thought the wagon at least had seen its best days and suggested getting a new one
Completed

It was the same man that you hired the team of he remembered you. When Maratta comes we both will go to Acoma he was to be here last night so I sat up until midnight to meet him & he did'nt come he may come to night but he will have to sleep in the depot on the floor if he does as I wont sit up again, which will give him a taste of what an Indian painter has to put up with. I see that some parties is digging an irrigating ditch near Ignacio Cal when I was for the Utes has discovered some old Aztec ruins and has dug up some fine pottery. Mr Marmon here who has surveyed all this country for the Government years ago tells me he knows now around here of several old ruins that have never been excavated.
Completed

The papers in New York City speak well of my 3 Indian portraits on exhibition in the Academy.
Your affect. nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Laguna.
New Mexico.
Feb.2.1900.
My Dear Uncle
Maratta has been with me for 3 weeks and was very enthusiastic over the motives here for pictures says it is better than anything in Italy. He has made some of the finest water colors I ever saw of the Laguna Pueblo but the poor fellow cant stand the altitude, that with the poor food (no nourishment in it) has knocked him out so that he is unable to work and returns to Chicago tonight, I want you to be sure and see
Completed

If one could get good nourishing food it would be better but the people here dont seem to know enough to raise vegetables so as to have onions turnips etc during the Winter the result is they eat cheap canned goods and most of the time pork we had pork here for a month three times a day.
Maratta will have his water colors he has made here on exhibition at the Art Institute which commences Feb 27th and I want you and Aunt Emma to go and see them Maratta had planned to stay with me right along but he cant stand roughing it, I am getting the best pictures ever painted here
Completed

I have ?s to San Diego Cal and before I start for the North will go There and rest up and get something to eat.
Has the Calortype people returned to you the three Indians pictures they are reproducing? And have you received the skin yet from Naiche?
Chief Joseph will be passing through Chicago soon on his way to Washington and he may come and see you.
With love to you both
Your affect" nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Oceanpark.
March.16.1900. California.
My dear Uncle
Yours recd I told those color type people to be sure and finish your pictures first and wrote your name on your three and address and they dd everything wrong, finished yours toward the last and delivered one to Thurber but Thurber writes me you have it by now.
I am feeling fine now have got all the Laguna bad? eating ? and pork out of me now but I was under a Doctors care here for a while and for a month felt bad. I am stopping here some 20 miles from Los Angeles.
Completed

electric cars ? there from here. I have me a small room and eat fish clams etc all the time and go in bathing in Ocean every day which is a fine tonic. Aunt Emma would of enjoyed being with me other day. I was walking bare footed along the beach and run across some men on the beach clamming I bought a dozen clams for 10 cts each as big as your hand and ate them same night there. now I go my self and dig for clams and eat them as fast as find them.
I have visited Mr Lummis editor of Land of Sunshine several times he likes to have me come, he is a fine fellow very bright and you would be interested in the house he is building, he is building
Completed

it him self does all the mason work and carpenter work even makes his own doors and windows each one fourth the house is finished, it is to built in a square with a big court in a center in which grows a big queer tree, he says it will take him six years to finish the house, the part that is finished the rooms he has decorated with old rare Indian curios. He has a little daughter who was from among the Indians at Isleta the Indians named her which is Turbese? translated means "A burst of sunshine" and that is just what she is a burst of sunshine. I have become quite well acquainted with Mr Campbell
Completed

who has the curio store. he has been expecting you in every day. I will be returning back to Laguna in a few weeks but will manage different about living.
I would like to make my house in Los Angeles where it is Summer all the time and flowers all the year round.
With love to you and Aunt Emma
Your affect. nephew
Elbridge.
P.S. The land of sunshine magazine is to have an article in about me also the Los Angeles Sunday times is to have a long article illustrated about me. Am glad you have the painted skin from Naiche I just got word from Pine Ridge that a Sioux named Kicking Bear has painted for me the Sun dance 4x6 put on a sheet.
Completed

HOTEL HOLLAND
H.Y. Ryan, Prop.
SHAWNEE, OKLA. Oct 31  1900
My dear Uncle
I am with the Kickapoo Indians now and had a deuce of a time to get them to sit for me. but finally succeeded in having one Come Today They have a village 16 miles from here I went out there but as there was no place to stop had to return, their houses are oval shape and made of a sort of long weed which they let dry before using. They dress their hair different from other Indians, They are pretty hard workers and are very suspicious in regard to having any pictures made
Completed

of Them, think I will get some good subjects here.
A squaw is the Chief of the tribe and she has a great deal of influence over them. The Agent tells me that in the history of the tribe squaws have been their Agent quite often. I want to remain around this part of country until Spring then have an exhibition possibly in April.
I did'nt have my wife come with me she wanted to come but I thought it best as I am pretty nervous yet and it is a good thing she did'nt come as there is so much malaria here I had a severe touch of it I am gradually coming around all right but
Completed

at one time thought I never would paint another Indian and it seems so nice to be back with them as I get along so nice with Them. I see that there are only 13 of the original Madocs left they are in Kansas I want to paint them also.
Did you see the pictures I did on last trip at Thurbers? In case you buy any no commission will be charged
The Santa Fe gave me a pass to Oklahoma City this place is on the Choctow R. R.
I want to if I can paint some from all the different
Completed

tribes in this Territory there are some 21 different tribes and of them all the Osages are The most picturesque and also the most difficult to get
Am glad I have got a Kickapoo to sit for me as They are so well known, living years ago in Indiana. There is a tribe of them in Old Mexico now that dress in their Indian clothes but quite a number of these have Indian clothes. I shall be glad to hear from you of course I am not my self yet but am in hopes to be soon. 
With love to you and Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

HOTEL HOLLAND
H.Y. RYAN, Prop,
11/3/00
SHAWNEE, OKLA., Nov 3 1900.
My dear Uncle
I have got these Indians now so can manage them but had a hard time as they are so superstitious they said that to have their picture painted it takes part of their spirit with it, but I finally got one fellow to sit a fine type and more commenced another one today and have another one waiting to sit. I saw the squaw and chief today she is a way lovely woman. But smart looking  They tell me She don't sit but I will bet
Completed

I will have her refuse? I have?  There are four tribes here viz. Kickapoos Shawnees Pottawattomie & Sac & Fox. I always
thought that the Sac & Fox was two tribes but it is one tribe, will paint some from each tribe will only my paint one squaw as they are
not saleable.

 You have'nt a Navajo Indian in your collection you should have at least one, on the chances are I never will paint any more of

them  You could get the one that is in Paris  She is a genuine Navajo and dressed in genuine old Navajo dress & Navajo blanket.
The Agent here is so well
Completed

HOTEL HOLLAND
H.Y. Ryan, Prop.
SHAWNEE, OKLA.,    1900
(3)
liked that the Indians in order to keep him and to be his boss notified the
Government that they would pay his salary themselfs which they did he is a fine
fellow and has been a great help to me.

 I am painting if any thing better than ever did. Did you see the Tribune for Oct 28? It has

a whole page of four of my Indians one of them you ought to have Ta-ba-ha-gah in queer costume.

I can't tell you how glad I am to be back with the Indians, but
Completed

I get more lonesome for my wife than ever did before. I wish
you would  ? me.

 I have had a mighty hard time of it but in the future wont work

so hard and will take a vacation once a year.  The small pox is
around here but I am not scared of it  I was quite sick with
Malaria but am over that now.  I am going to get in portrait of 
every single tribe here and there are 21   and it is funny living
among civilization as long as they have? they are as good subjects for

me as the Siouxs as they have so many Indian clothes Indian trinkets etc.
Completed

HOTEL HOLLAND
H.Y. Ryan, Prop.
(5)  SHAWNEE, OKLA.    1900
I am paying them $1.50 a day they wanted more but I would not
give it  The squaw Chief may want more.

 When do you sail for Europe  and what address will ? you 

I wrote Mc Neil about the war bonnett hav'nt heard from him as yet.

 The Kickapoos wear a thing on their head made from the whiskers of a wild Turkey
then dyed and they are nicely made  each hair is woven in separately and takes weeks 

to make it.
Completed

I am not yet quite myself yet but am getting so gradually  and
here after will keep both eyes wide open.

 With love to you and Aunt Emma

Your affectionate nephew

Elbridge
Completed

HOTEL HOLLAND
H.Y. Ryan, Prop.
Shawnee, Okla., Nov 12 1900.
My dear Uncle,
I am not having such a soft time with these Indians as anticipated  have only succeeded in getting them to sit for me,

they are so superstitious and them living all around this town it is hard to get at them. I leave today for the Sac & Fox Indians. 

Years ago these Indians were one tribe and they had some trouble and separated one party took the name of Saux or Sac and

the other part; Fox after awhile they
Completed

became friendly and joined hand and now are known as the Sac & Fox  They are only a few miles from here The Agent here

is going to try  his best to get the Squaw  Chief to sit for me if he succeeds he is to let me know and I will return and paint her.

The Sac & Fox live on their reservation and I don't anticipate any trouble in getting them   the two Kickapoos I have one 
fine type all painted up in Kickapoo style. 
I was exposed to the small pox here but didn't catch it
Completed

HOTEL HOLLAND
H.Y. Ryan, Prop.
Shawnee, Okla., 1900.
I went out to the Kickapoo village ago and thy had the Smallpox which I was not aware of an [unclear] not have gone out there. 
With love to you and Aunt Emma.
Your affectionate nephew 

 Elbridge

P.S.  Would like to hear from you 

unclear.... had bought one of the Laguna Indians  Thanks
Address

Sac & Fox Agency Okla. T. 
11.12.00
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Nov. 14. 1900
My dear Uncle

 I arrived here last night.  It is generally sufficient that Keokuk the old

son of Keokuk that Keokuk Iowa was named after is dead
some three years ago I saw in print that he was dead but he
is not and is sitting for a picture for me,  commenced it this noon
Completed

He is a fine type of a man 74 years old and dont look 54
he has a profile just like Henry Ward Beecher  I will  try and get him
to sit for two portraits if can but doubtful about it as he is getting
tired of sitting  already the ?int? types and in fact meant of the
Sac & Fox live some 20 miles from here in their village  so I may
go there. Am glad my painting Keokuk he is head Chief of the tribe.

 I am stopping at the worst looking
Completed

Hotel ever was in, in my life, the board isn't bad but my room is terrible. 
have seen pig pens that were better, there is absolutely no furniture in the room

but a bed and such a bed, it is the best I can do  here, but as long as the board

is good I dont mind.  They charge $4.00 a week room and board

 The November Brush & Pencil has an article in on Indians in Act? I ?

mind you would get one & see what you think of it.
Completed

The Sac & Fox Indians are well fixed and receive $42.00  per head every
three months, they live in good houses. The interpreter here is an old Sac & Fox
Indian and he has told me quite a good deal about his life  Their cast..?
dress & fight  years ? The Sioux men their worst enemies.

 I would like to hear from you, sometimes I feel as though all my friends

had deserted me on account of my trouble and terrible mistake  I made  but
Completed

Uncle Ed I surely was not my self then as was all run down in every way  but am gradually gaining but slowly.

With love to you and Aunt Emma
 Your affectionate nephew
  Elbridge
Completed

11/19/00
Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Nov. 19. 1900

 My dear Uncle
  Yous received & glad to hear from you  No I did not know that

Black hawk was a Sac & Fox  I did not know before that the Sac Indians ever
fought the Fox Indians this is news to me   probably that was the time that two tribes

had their quarrel and separated and after several years became friends  and have

been so ever since   Keokuk is a Sac Indian but it is a
Completed

question whether the old original Keokuk was his Father  they tell me here that they think 
that Keokuks Mother married Old Keokuk after the present Keokuk was born  but it is a question
Keokuks  wifes Mother made her escape during the Black hawk war  by swimming the Mississippi River
with her child on her back.

 Keokuk remembers the Black hawk war well & tousnow? are young to talk with him about it. 

He is a wise old fellow a devout Christian.  I tried to
Completed

get him to sit for me today  but he said it made him very tired and he guessed he
would not.  so I think I will go some 20 miles from here to the Sac & Fox village
there is one white man there and they tell me I can get some fine types there.

 No  I wont work so hard and will take it easier in the future and do all I can to

get back where I was  I wrote an article about the Kickapoos & Sac & Fox
Indians and other things for
Completed

the Chicago Post  The Sac & Fox Indians are all big strong built Indians  and
they & the Shawnees & Kickapoos  language is way similar.

 I will try & paint some Shawnees  but these Indians in this part of the Territory are hard

to get at  as they mingle so with civilization

 I see now a railroad runs into Ft Sill and when that country is opened up it will be hard to

get at them   With love to you & Aunt Emma

 Your affectionate nephew
   Elbridge
Completed

11/20/00
Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Nov. 20. 1900
My dear Uncle

 Yours just at hand, as soon as Keokuks picture is dry enough I will send it

to you by Express.   I had to paint him in civilian clothes as he said he abandoned
Indian clothes 40 years ago.  I prevailed on him to sit for another portrait

a profile he has a wonderful profile  just like
Completed

Henry Ward Beecher.

I asked Keokuk today about Black hawk & he said he was a Sac & Fox Indian  said he knew him. 

he talks but very little English but understand all. Tomorrow I will get the interpreter and have a talk with Keokuk.
I went to church last Sunday which pleased Keokuk as he shook hands with me in Church.  I hardly think
I will go out to the Sac & Fox
Completed

(3)
village  they tell me there is only one Chief there and that he is a mean fellow
hard to manage but I would'nt care for that but was thinking where could stop
there  There is a farmer there or a mile from there   I may go, no mail goes
there at all  The advantage in going there is the Indians dress more in their
native dress that is some of them shave their head similar to the Osage  but
Completed

different  It hardly pays to paint only Chiefs unless the others have a fine
costume and good strong face.  The hunting is fine here  Ducks & Quails
and last night a Deer passed through the Agency the Indians saw his tracks
The food at the Hotel is'nt bad but every thing else is awful  I could buy all the
furniture  in this house including dishes and tin ware for $5.00
Completed

It seems I am the only white man that stops here  The other customers are Indians  one sleeps in
my room every night.  Guess I told you of a lot of drunken Indians stopping here over night  They 
saw me and said you white man come here  so I went and they offered me a drink of Alcohol
which I refused but one big Indian grabbed me  so I drank a very little of it and got away.
Completed

soon as possible.  I am taking good care of myself and am taking it easier
and not working so hard. The Boston Museum bought a set of signed 
proofs? of my Indians reproductions.  I wish now I had got some good
business man and gone into that Indian reproduction business myself or
else not had them reproduced in colors at all.  I want to get through
Completed

with the Indians in Okla. T. this time that is the tribes that live East of the
Rock Island R.R. as there are so many of them.  I think the Wichitas have
only one Chief  To-walk-Ken-ey*. Jim they call him  I have met him and he was
to sit for me but he was building a fence at the time & could'nt get any
one to take his place  so  did'nt get him.

Tawakoni
Completed

Hope you will like   Keokuk picture I have a splendid likeness of him  he wanted the
picture himself  he has several pictures in his house of his Father also himself in
younger days. In a dew days will send Keokuks picture to you but it will be some
time before it can be varnished and I can do that when am in Chicago. Am so glad to
hear from you

 Your affectionate nephew
  Elbridge

P.S. Excuse paper.
